title: 112_hr3829
content: The "Childcare Accountability and Responsibility Act of 2012" or the "CARE for Kids Act of 2012" requires a criminal background check under the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990. The "CARE for Kids Act of 2012" mandates a criminal background check for child care staff, family child care providers, and adults living in the home of a family child care provider. The check includes searches of the National Sex Offender Registry, National Crime Information Center, and State criminal registry. The "CARE for Kids Act of 2012" requires criminal background checks for child care staff and family child care providers. This includes searches of State criminal registries, abuse and neglect databases, and FBI fingerprint checks. Providers will be ineligible for funds if a staff member or provider fails the background check. The "CARE for Kids Act of 2012" mandates criminal background checks for child care staff and family child care providers. If a check reveals an adult felony conviction for child abuse, spousal abuse, crimes against children, violent crimes, or drug offenses within 5 years, the individual is disqualified. The "CARE for Kids Act of 2012" requires child care providers to undergo State and national criminal background checks. Individuals with certain felony convictions within 5 years, including drug offenses, are disqualified. Requests for background checks must be submitted to the designated State agency. The "Responsibility Act of 2012" mandates background checks for child care staff and family providers every 5 years. Prospective staff and providers must undergo checks before starting their roles. The "Responsibility Act of 2012" requires background checks for child care staff and family providers every 5 years. Only one request for a State and national criminal background check is needed for each individual during a 5-year period. The "Responsibility Act of 2012" mandates background checks for child care staff and family providers every 5 years. Results of the criminal background check must be provided within 10 business days of the request. States must give a copy of the background check to the individual upon request. The "Responsibility Act of 2012" requires background checks for child care staff and family providers every 5 years. States must ensure accuracy of information in the background check by obtaining dispositions of arrests over 1 year old, correcting inaccuracies, completing incomplete entries, and taking steps to improve accuracy. Appeals process is also available. The "Responsibility Act of 2012" mandates background checks for child care staff and family providers every 5 years. States must ensure accuracy by obtaining arrest dispositions, correcting errors, and improving information quality. An appeals process is available for individuals to challenge background check results within 30 days. The "Responsibility Act of 2012" mandates background checks for child care staff and family providers every 5 years. States must ensure accuracy by obtaining arrest dispositions, correcting errors, and improving information quality. An appeals process is available for individuals to challenge background check results within 30 days. Fees may be collected from child care providers for criminal background checks to cover administration costs. The Childcare Accountability and Responsibility Act of 2012 requires states to conduct criminal background checks on child care providers, with a maximum fee of $36. States must comply with the law within 3 years, with a possible 2-year extension for good faith efforts. Definitions include an adult as someone over 18 and a child care provider as specified. The term 'adult' refers to a person who is 18 years or older. A 'child care provider' is a center-based or group home provider of child care services for compensation, licensed, regulated, or funded under State law. A 'child care staff member' is an individual who provides child care services for compensation on a regular basis. The term 'family child care provider' refers to an individual who provides child care services for fewer than 24 hours per day, as the sole caregiver, in a private residence, and is licensed, regulated, or registered under State law or receives funds provided under this subchapter. Authorization of appropriations is granted to conduct criminal background checks for family child care providers under State law or receiving funds under this subchapter.
